case_name: State of Madhya Pradesh v. Chhotahhai Jethabhai Patel

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 684 of 1968 was filed.

facts.text: Madhya Pradesh Tendu Patta Vyapar Viniyaman Adhiniyam, 1964 enacted to regulate trade by creating state monopoly.

anchor.surface_text: In order to find out whether the action of the Forest Officer was justified, we have to look into the relevant provisions of the Act and the rules framed thereunder. The Act as its preamble shows is one to make provision for regulating in the public interest the trade of tendu leaves by creation of State monopoly in such trade.

facts.text: High Court issued writ quashing complaint, appealed by State.

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal from a judgment of the Madhya Pradesh High Court quashing the proceedings initiated on the companyplaint filed by the Divisional Forest Officer, Saugor in the Court of the Magistrate of the First Class Saugor for imposition of a penalty on the respondents. The matter arises thus. Chhotahhai Jethabhai Patel, a partnership firm of which the second respondent, Jhaverbhai Bhulabhai Patel is a partner, carried on business on a fairly large scale as manufacturers of bidis at various places in the State of Madhya Pradesh including Saugor. Being unable to secure sufficient quantities of tendu leaves grown in the forest units in the State, the firm took leases for the companylection of such leaves in the States of Bihar Maharashtra. They actually imported tendu leaves under two railway companysignments from Bihar to Saugor. They informed the Divisional Forest Officer about the same and asked for permission for transport of the leaves and to utilise the said leaves for manufacture of bidis in their factories. By letter dated July 27, 1965 the said Forest Officer intimated the firm that the imported leaves were number to be moved for bidi manufacture until permission was accorded for so doing. The respondents grievance was that numberwithstanding the above companymunication and in spite of the fact that they had number moved the imported leaves from their godowns, the Sub Divisional Forest Officer Saugor seized two quantities of such leaves of 9007 bags imported from Garwah Road, Bihar and 256 bags of tendu leaves imported from Bindoumaganj, Bihar and followed the same up by filing a companyplaint alleging companytravention of s. 5 of the Madhya Pradesh Tendu Patta Wyapar Viniyaman  84 0 Adhiniyam, 1964, hereinafter referred to as the Act. The respondents filed a petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution before the High Court for the issue of a writ of certiorari quashing the companyplaint.

Art. 226 of the Constitution before the High Court for the issue of a writ of certiorari quashing the complaint. The contention of the respondents importers of the leaves before the High Court was that the Act did not prohibit the import of tendu leaves from places outside the State nor was there any restriction on a manufacturer importing such leaves with the express object of consumption of the same, in his factory for the manufacture of bidis and in any event the Act or the Rules made thereunder did not purport to regulate the transport of tendu leaves imported from places outside the State. On behalf of the State it was contended that transport of tendu leaves whether grown in the State or outside the State was completely prohibited by s. 5(2) of the Act and regulation and control of transport of such imported leaves was necessary for the successful working of the State monopoly in the trade of tendu leaves envisaged by the Act.

filing a complaint alleging contravention of s. 5 of the Madhya Pradesh Tendu Patta Vyapar Viniyaman  84 0 Adhiniyam, 1964, hereinafter referred to as the Act. The respondents filed a petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution before the High Court for the issue of a writ of certiorari quashing the complaint. The contention of the respondents importers of the leaves before the High Court was that the Act did not prohibit the import of tendu leaves from places outside the State nor was there any restriction on a manufacturer importing such leaves with the express object of consumption of the same, in his factory for the manufacture of bidis and in any event the Act or the Rules made thereunder did not purport to regulate the transport of tendu leaves imported from places outside the State.

anchor.surface_text: Under s. 15 any person contravening any of the provisions of the Act or the rules thereunder was liable to punishment, both with imprisonment and fine and tendu leaves in respect of which such contravention took place were liable to forfeiture by Government. S. 19 gave the Government power to make rules to carry out the provisions of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: the latter part of Art. 19(6). If there are other provisions made by the Act which are subsidiary, incidental or helpful to the operation of the monopoly, they do not fall under the said part and their validity must be judged under the first part of Art. 19(6). In other words, the effect of the amendment made in Art. 19(6) is to protect the law relating to the creation of monopoly and that means that it is only the provisions of the law which are integrally and essentially connected with the creation of the monopoly that are protected.

concepts.interpretation: Protects essential provisions of state monopoly laws; subsidiary provisions tested under general restrictions.

It is settled law that where two constructions of a legislative provision are possible one consistent with the constitutionality of the measure impugned and the other offending the same, the Court will lean towards the first if it be compatible with the object and purpose of the impugned Act, the mischief which it sought to prevent ascertaining from relevant factors its true scope and meaning.

issues.text: Whether s.5 and the Act confine the monopoly and restrictions to tendu leaves grown within the State

anchor.surface_text: Rule 4 framed under the Act lays down the kinds of transport permits which may be issued. They are to be of four types (i) for transport from collection depot to storage godown (ii) for transport from one storage godown to another or to distribution centre (iii) for transport from a distribution centre to Sattedars or Mazdoors and (iv) for transport outside the State. The application for a transport permit is to be under rule 9 in form M and the permit to be issued is to be in form M. Form M gives the quantity of tendu leaves purchased, the place or places where they were stored, the destination to which they were to be transported and the place or places where transported leaves were to be stored. Similar particulars are to be contained in a permit in form N. It was contended on behalf of the State that the High Court had gone wrong in taking the view that the object of the Act was confined to trading in tendu leaves grown in the State as disclosed by the above provisions.

issues.text: Whether restrictions on transport of tendu leaves are integrally and essentially connected with the creation of the State monopoly and protected by the latter part of Article 19(6)

anchor.surface_text: the latter part of Art. 19(6). In other words, the effect of the amendment made in Art. 19(6) is to protect the law relating to the creation of monopoly and that means that it is only the provisions of the law which are integrally and essentially connected with the creation of the monopoly that are protected.

issues.text: Whether an express embargo on import of tendu leaves from outside the State or restriction on their movement within the State would offend provisions of Part XIII of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: In any event, the Act ought not to be construed so as to ban import of tendu leaves from outside the State or restrict their movement once they were within the State unless clear language was used in that behalf. If and when such express embargo is imposed, a question may arise as to whether it offends the different provisions of Part XIII of the Constitution.

holdings.text: All the relevant provisions of the Act and the rules referred to above show that the legislature intended that everybody growing leaves within the State should offer the same to it or its agents in different units for sale and the State was bound to purchase every single lot of tendu leaves unless the same could be said to be unfit for the manufacture of bidis.

anchor.surface_text: We find ourselves unable to accept the contentions put forward by counsel on behalf of the State. All the relevant provisions of the Act and the rules referred to above show that the legislature intended that everybody growing leaves within the State should offer the same to it or its agents in different units for sale and the State was bound to purchase every single lot of tendu leaves unless the same could be said to be unfit for the manufacture of bidis.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Provisions of ss.3,5(1) and rules specify 'unit in which the leaves have grown'; scheme requires growers in State to offer to State agents.

holdings.text: Without expressing our views on the subject we hold that the entire provisions of the Act and the rules are consistent with and aim at the State monopoly in the trade of tendu leaves in case of leaves grown or produced in the State and the legislature never intended that the monopoly should be operative even to the extent of banning import of tendu leaves from outside or stalling the tendu leaves once they found their way into the State from outside.

anchor.surface_text: Without expressing our views on the subject we hold that the entire provisions of the Act and the rules are consistent with and aim at the State monopoly in the trade of tendu leaves in case of leaves grown or produced in the State and the legislature never intended that the monopoly should be operative even to the extent of banning import of tendu leaves from outside or stalling the tendu leaves once they found their way into the State from outside.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Act confines to state-grown leaves; no provision bans import or regulates imported leaves' transport; avoids constitutional invalidity.

holdings.text: The transport of tendu leaves purchased outside but consigned to places within the State to be used for the manufacture of bidis is not integrally connected with the State monopoly as envisaged in the Act.

anchor.surface_text: The transport of tendu leaves purchased outside but consigned to places within the, State to be used for the manufacture of bidis is not integrally connected with the State monopoly as envisaged in the Act. It stands to reason that manufacturers of bidis in the State of Madhya Pradesh would not think of importing tendu leaves from distant places like, Bihar and Maharashtra if they could help it and it must be the exigencies of the situation which drives a manufacturer of bidis to such course of action.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Trade is purchase/sale; post-purchase transport not essential to monopoly per precedents in Vrajlal and Akadasi; manufacturers import only if necessary.

holdings.text: Prima facie trade in tendu leaves would consist of dealing in those leaves i.e. their purchase and sale but transport of the leaves once purchased or sold would not prima facie be an organic or integral part of dealing in those leaves.

anchor.surface_text: Prima facie trade in tendu leaves as was held by this Court in Vrajlal Manilal v. M. P. State would consist of dealing in those leaves i.e. their purchase and sale but transport of the leaves once purchased or sold would not prima facie be an organic or integral part of dealing in those leaves.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Following Vrajlal precedent defining trade as dealing (purchase/sale); transport separate.

holdings.text: It is only the provisions of the law which are integrally and essentially connected with the creation of the monopoly that are protected by the latter part of Art. 19(6).

anchor.surface_text: In other words, the effect of the amendment made in Art. 19(6) is to protect the law relating to the creation of monopoly and that means that it is only the provisions of the law which are integrally and essentially connected with the creation of the monopoly that are protected.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applying Akadasi Padhan: distinguishes essential monopoly provisions (protected) from subsidiary (tested under first part of Art.19(6)).

holdings.text: In any event, the Act ought not to be construed so as to ban import of tendu leaves from outside the State or restrict their movement once they were within the State unless clear language was used in that behalf.

anchor.surface_text: In any event, the Act ought not to be construed so as to ban import of tendu leaves from outside the State or restrict their movement once they were within the State unless clear language was used in that behalf.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Harmonious construction prefers reading consistent with constitutionality and Act's object; no clear language for broader scope.

holdings.text: If and when such express embargo is imposed, a question may arise as to whether it offends the different provisions of Part XIII of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: If and when such express embargo is imposed, a question may arise as to whether it offends the different provisions of Part XIII of the Constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Hypothetical future case; no decision on merits.

precedents.citation: Vrajlal Manilal v. M. P. State 1 1970 1 S.C.R. 400 at 408

anchor.surface_text: Vrajlal Manilal v. M. P. State 1  would companysist of dealing in those leaves i.e. their purchase and sale but transport of the leaves once purchased or sold would number prima facie be an organic or integral part of dealing in those leaves. It was further held in that case a permit system which regulates the movement of leaves purchased by a manufacturer of bidis from the unit where they are purchased to his warehouse, then to the branches and to the sattedars cannot up to that stage be regarded as unreasonable in the light of the object of the Act, the economic companyditions prevailing in the State, and the mischief which it seeks to cure.

precedents.case_name: Vrajlal Manilal v. M. P. State
precedents.cited_proposition: trade in tendu leaves consists of purchase and sale, transport not prima facie integral part; permit system reasonable up to transport to sattedars but unreasonable for distribution to mazdoors; section 5 has inherent limitations from object of Act
precedents.cited_holding: permit system which regulates the movement of leaves purchased by a manufacturer of bidis from the unit where they are purchased to his warehouse, then to the branches and to the sattedars cannot up to that stage be regarded as unreasonable [...] though the section is couched in apparently wide language, the very object of the Act [...] contains inherent limitations against an absolute or as strictly regulated a ban

precedents.citation: Akadasi Padhan v. State of Orissa 1 1963 Supp. 2 S.C.R. 691

anchor.surface_text: Akadasi Padhan v. State of Orissa 1  A law relating to a State monopoly cannot, in the context, include all the provisions contained in the said law whether they have direct relation with the creation of the monopoly or notthe said expression should be construed to mean the law relating to the monopoly in its absolutely essential features.

precedents.case_name: Akadasi Padhan v. State of Orissa
precedents.cited_proposition: law relating to state monopoly protects under latter part of Art. 19(6) only essential and basic provisions integrally connected with creation of monopoly; subsidiary, incidental provisions judged under first part of Art. 19(6)
precedents.cited_holding: A law relating to a State monopoly cannot, in the context, include all the provisions contained in the said law whether they have direct relation with the creation of the monopoly or not [...] it is only the provisions of the law which are integrally and essentially connected with the creation of the monopoly that are protected.

anchor.surface_text: We find ourselves unable to accept the contentions put forward by counsel on behalf of the State. All the relevant provisions of the Act and the rules referred to above show that the legislature intended that everybody growing leaves within the State should offer the same to it or its agents in different units for sale and the State was bound to purchase every single lot of tendu leaves unless the same could be said to be unfit for the manufacture of bidis.

outcome.relief_summary: Contentions of the State rejected; Act does not regulate import or transport of tendu leaves from outside the State; High Court order quashing proceedings upheld

edges.explanation: The holding explicitly decides the issue by stating that the provisions of the Act and rules are consistent with the State monopoly in tendu leaves trade, addressing whether the Act prohibits or restricts import.

anchor.surface_text: Without expressing our views on the subject we hold that the entire provisions of the Act and the rules are consistent with and aim at the State monopoly in the trade of tendu leaves in case of leaves grown or produced in the State and the legislature never intended that the monopoly should be operative even to the extent of banning import of tendu leaves from outside or stalling the tendu leaves once they found their way into the State from outside.

We find ourselves unable to accept the contentions put forward by counsel on behalf of the State. All the relevant provisions of the Act and the rules referred to above show that the legislature intended that everybody growing leaves within the State should offer the same to it or its agents in different units for sale and the State was bound to purchase every single lot of tendu leaves unless the same could be said to be unfit for the manufacture of bidis.

anchor.surface_text: The transport of tendu leaves purchased outside but consigned to places within the, State to be used for the manufacture of bidis is not integrally connected with the State monopoly as envisaged in the Act. It stands to reason that manufacturers of bidis in the State of Madhya Pradesh would not think of importing tendu leaves from distant places like, Bihar and Maharashtra if they could help it and it must be the exigencies of the situation which drives a manufacturer of bidis to such course of action.

We find ourselves unable to accept the contentions put forward by counsel on behalf of the State. All the relevant provisions of the Act and the rules referred to above show that the legislature intended that everybody growing leaves within the State should offer the same to it or its agents in different units for sale and the State was bound to purchase every single lot of tendu leaves unless the same could be said to be unfit for the manufacture of bidis.

Prima facie trade in tendu leaves as was held by this Court in Vrajlal Manilal v. M. P. State would consist of dealing in those leaves i.e. their purchase and sale but transport of the leaves once purchased or sold would not prima facie be an organic or integral part of dealing in those leaves.

We find ourselves unable to accept the contentions put forward by counsel on behalf of the State.
